docs.lead_paragraph: The public relations war over President Bush's Social Security plan escalated on Wednesday, as a liberal advocacy group attacked the Republican chairman of the House Social Security subcommittee, and conservative groups fought among themselves over strategy. The advocacy group, Campaign for America's Future, accused the subcommittee chairman, Representative Jim McCrery of Louisiana, of conflict of interest, saying he had accepted nearly $200,000 in contributions over four years from securities firms and commercial banks that could benefit from Mr. Bush's plan to let workers invest in retirement accounts.

headline.main: Flare-Ups in Battle to Push or Bury Bush Social Security Plan

docs.abstract: Public relations war over Pres Bush's Social Security plan escalates, as liberal advocacy group Campaign for America's Future attacks Republican chairman of House Social Security subcommittee Rep Jim McCrery and conservative groups fight among themselves over strategy; advocacy group accuses McCrery of conflict of interest, saying he accepted $200,000 in contributions over four years from securities firms and commercial banks that could benefit from Bush's plan; group will run newspaper advertisement against McCrery, who has responded by accusing group of 'extreme liberal bias'; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The public relations war escalated on Wednesday, as a liberal advocacy group attacked the Republican chairman of the House Social Security subcommittee.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and RICHARD W. STEVENSON; Glen Justice contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone looking for clues as to how the Bush administration might overhaul the Medicaid system should come to Utah and read the fine print of Tony Martinez's health insurance plan. Mr. Martinez, 56, was homeless and without any health coverage a year ago. Now, under an experimental plan of partial insurance devised under Michael O. Leavitt when he was governor of Utah, Mr. Martinez can see a doctor or go to the emergency room for only a small fee.

headline.main: Model in Utah May Be Future For Medicaid

docs.abstract: Bush administration effort to overhaul Medicaid system may use program in Utah as model; Michael O Leavitt, Pres Bush's new secretary of health and human services, is promoting Medicaid plan in Utah that was adopted when he was governor; his plan departs from traditional Medicaid program on two main fronts; it spreads out lower, more basic level of care to more people, and reduces coverage for some traditional beneficiaries by imposing co-payments on service, and it relies on generosity of doctors and hospitals to provide services free of charge for those needing extended hospitalization or specialty medical treatment; medical experts say that program broadens focus from question of who does and does not have health insurance, to what constitutes basic health coverage; many academics and health care analysts say they worry that substantial state-by-state Medicaid experiments could fracture and fragment system that has evolved into anchor of health coverage for poor since its introduction in 1960's; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Michael O. Leavitt, who is leading a drive to change Medicaid, often points to Utah as an example for other states.

byline.original: By KIRK JOHNSON and REED ABELSON; Kirk Johnson reported from Salt Lake City and Reed Abelson from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than two months after he was elected, Mayor Alberto Ruiz Flores climbed in his truck and set out on a 26-hour road trip across the border to Southern California, carrying a wish list of public works projects to a backyard barbecue in Oxnard. The reason? To solicit money from some of the 400,000 Mexicans who abandon their country each year for work in the United States, including half his town in Central Mexico. Those who have left Valparaíso send home an estimated $100,000 a day, as much money in one month as the municipality will spend all year.

headline.main: Mexico's Migrants Profit From Dollars Sent Home

docs.abstract: Financial remittances sent home by Mexican migrants working in United States, both legal and illegal, as well as those from other places in Central America and Caribbean, are being translated into political clout in their home communities; migrants' communities in United States are better organized and more vocal than before and have become social and political forces too important to ignore at home; half the people of Valparaiso, Mexico, have left to work in United States, sending home an estimated $100,000 a day, as much money in one month as municipality will spend all years; Mayor Alberto Ruiz Flores travels to places like Oxnard, Calif, and Aurora, Ill, to solicit funds for public works projects in Valparaiso; in addition, countries like Mexico and Dominican Republic are taking steps to allow their citizens living in United States to cast absentee ballots in elections; map shows amount of remittances sent from various US states, to various places in Mexico; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Mexican officials answer to people at home who cast ballots and the ones abroad who pull the purse strings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaking before hundreds of doctors and medical workers in a St. Louis suburb last month, President Bush called attention to a neurosurgeon on stage with him in the small auditorium. The doctor, the president said, was paying $265,000 a year in premiums for insurance against malpractice claims. Such high prices, ''don't start in an examining room or an operating room,'' the president declared. ''They start in a courtroom.''
docs.abstract: Legal costs do not seem to be root of recent increase in malpractice insurance premiums; government and industry data show only modest rise in malpractice claims over last decade; trend in payments in 2004 for malpractice claims against doctors and other medical professionals turned sharply downward, falling 8.9 percent, to nationwide total of $4.6 billion; specialists say more important factors for rise in premiums appear to be declining investment earnings of insurance companies and changing nature of completition in inudstry; graph (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush has complained about the "skyrocketing" costs of "junk lawsuits" against doctors, but legal costs are not at the root of the increase in malpractice premiums.

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER and JOEL BRINKLEY

docs.lead_paragraph: OVER the last several years, John Votta's accounting office in Haddon Township, N.J., has gotten progressively less cluttered, with computer programs replacing piles of files and papers. Yet that doesn't mean his workload has shrunk, especially when dealing with his small-business clients. ''They call them tax simplification acts,'' Mr. Votta said of the bills that Congress passes periodically. ''But often it is just a reduction of tax rates. Don't confuse that with simplicity. The rules, especially for small businesses, just seem to become more and more complicated.''

headline.main: When It's Tax Time, Call In the Professionals

docs.abstract: Article offers advice to small business entrepreneurs on what they need to do to prepare business taxes; focuses on importance of finding qualified tax professionals and keeping records of business expenses separate from personal spending; drawing (special section: Small Business) (M)
docs.snippet: The starting point for small-business owners is to remember that they are dealing with a new entity, not only their individual taxes.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Bush Cautions Russia On Democratic Reforms President Bush warned Russia that it ''must renew a commitment to democracy and the rule of law,'' but said he believed that the nation's future lay ''within the family of Europe and the trans-Atlantic community.'' Mr. Bush was speaking at the start of a four-day trip aimed at building a new relationship with Europe. A1 Recruiting Gays to British Navy Five years after Britain lifted its ban on gays in the military, the Royal Navy announced that it had partnered with a gay rights group to begin actively encouraging gays to enlist. A1 Afghan Standards Lag Behind Three years after the United States-led war there, Afghanistan ranked 173rd of 178 countries in the United Nations 2004 Human Development Index, according to a new report. A3 3 Journalists Flee Zimbabwe Three reporters for major international news organizations have fled Zimbabwe after police searched their offices and threatened to arrest the three for espionage and slandering the state. A3 Attackers Changing in Mosul Militant Islamist groups that originated in Iraqi Kurdistan are responsible for most of the attacks now taking place in the insurgent stronghold of Mosul, while activity by nationalist insurgents linked to the former government has slowed there, senior Kurdish officials say. A9 Palestinians Released in Israel Israel freed 500 Palestinian prisoners, the latest good-will gesture intended to strengthen a truce that has largely been holding. A7 The Same Promise From Syria Syria repeated longstanding promises to withdraw its troops from Lebanon, as tens of thousands of people marched through the streets of Beirut in the largest anti-Syrian protests since the killing a week earlier of the former prime minister. A7 NATIONAL A10-15 Rains Cause Deaths In Southern California A long weekend of drenching rain left Southern California with flooded houses, washed-out roads and cascading mud, and caused the deaths of at least three people, one of them a 16-year-old girl killed by a boulder that smashed into her bedroom. A10 Land Dispute in Nevada Nevada's Bureau of Land Management and a family of Paiute Indians are debating the rights to 160 acres because the family's patriarch neglected to have an official witness sign the deed to his homestead 60 years ago. A10 Medicare Coverage Debate Drug companies are strenuously resisting bipartisan efforts in Congress to prohibit Medicare from paying for Viagra and other drugs for erectile dysfunction. A12 Water Battles in the Court A flurry of cases in California involving water disputes are attracting attention from scholars and government officials who see them as an extraordinary assault by agricultural interests on protections for endangered fish and other wildlife. A15 Minnesota Plays Poker Politics As televised tournaments make poker ever more popular and mainstream, Minnesota is one of at least half a dozen states grappling with a new phenomenon: poker games with little or no stakes. State lawmakers are considering a bill that would explicitly legalize Texas Hold'em, but not other forms of poker, so long as prizes do not top $200. A1 Social Security Point Man Representative Jim McCrery of Louisiana has gone from being a little-known lawmaker to a central figure in the Social Security debate after being tutored on the finer points of President Bush's plan by four emissaries from the White House, including the new director of the president's National Economic Council. A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Budget Proposes Halt In Housing Aid for Disabled The Bush administration is proposing to stop financing the construction of new housing for the mentally ill and physically handicapped as part of a 50 percent cut in its housing budget for people with disabilities. B3 Senator's Job Rating Rises Recent polls have shown that Hillary Rodham Clinton, the junior senator from New York, may have turned a corner politically, sharply reducing the number of voters in the state who harbor negative views of her. B1 Profits for Conversion As it seeks to close a $4.15 billion budget gap and meet the state's growing health care, education and transportation needs, the Pataki administration is hoping to tap into a huge pot of money -- more than $2 billion -- by converting the HIP Health Plan into a for-profit company. B1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-10 Health & Fitness F5 FASHION B10 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-7 ARTS E1-10 Play to Bypass Broadway ''Hurlyburly,'' the revival of David Rabe's portrait of 80's excess, is transferring to a new Off Broadway theater on West 37th Street, outside the Theater District. E1 OBITUARIES B9 Robert R. Merhige Jr. Retired federal district judge who ordered the desegregation of many Virginia school districts, he was 86. B9 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Novartis to Buy Hexal Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, said it planned to buy Hexal of Germany and its affiliate Eon Labs of New York for $8.4 billion in cash, creating the world's biggest maker of generic drugs. C1 Lawsuits and Medical Costs President Bush has assailed malpractice lawsuits as a primary cause of rising medical expenses, but government and industry data indicate that legal costs may not be at the root of the recent increase in malpractice insurance premiums. C1 Deal in Works for Weinsteins Harvey Weinstein is expected to meet this week with executives for the Walt Disney Company for a final round of negotiations that would allow him and his brother to leave Disney when their contract expires, according to people involved in the negotiations. C1 Business Digest C1 Small Business G1-11 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: Tackling election reform; children and AIDS; post-scream strategizing; Francis X. Clines on how Pale Male and flocks of others fly freely for their annual census. Column: Paul Krugman. Crossword E6 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E9 Weather D8
docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    Bush Cautions Russia On Democratic Reforms  President Bush warned Russia that it ''must renew a commitment to democracy and the rule of law,'' but said he believed that the nation's future lay ''within the family of Europe and...

docs.lead_paragraph: As it seeks to close a $4.15 billion budget gap and meet the state's growing health care, education and transportation needs, the Pataki administration is hoping to tap into a huge pot of money -- more than $2 billion -- by converting the HIP Health Plan into a for-profit company. The planned conversion of HIP, one of New York's largest heath insurers, has already set off a scramble, with city, state and union officials jockeying to receive large chunks of the potential new revenue source either to pay for health coverage for public employees and public health programs or to help reduce large deficits.

headline.main: Budget Counts On a Windfall To Ease a Gap

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki's administration hopes to tap into more than $2 billion that could be generated if HIP Health Plan converts to for-profit company; is counting on initial $400 million to help close part of state's $4.15-budget deficit for 2006 fiscal year; analysts warn that getting money is far from certain; cite experience with conversion of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in 2002; $754 million from that move is tied-up in escrow awaiting court action; financial watchdogs and State Comptroller Alan G Hevesi warn that when funds from conversion run out, costs to state will still continue; Pataki administration says liquidation of nonprofit insurer happens over time and that funds will flow in over decade or more; says there will be time to reconcile gaps (M)
docs.snippet: The Pataki administration is hoping to tap into a huge pot of money - more than $2 billion - by converting the HIP Health Plan into a for-profit company.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HIP HEALTH PLAN OF NEW YORK

docs.lead_paragraph: Drug companies are strenuously resisting bipartisan efforts in Congress to prohibit Medicare from paying for Viagra and other drugs for erectile dysfunction. The issue of whether Medicare's new prescription drug benefit should cover such treatments is raising broader questions of ethics, economics, politics and health policy.

headline.main: Companies Fight to Ensure Coverage for Erectile Drugs

docs.abstract: Drug companies are strenuously resisting bipartisan efforts in Congress to prohibit Medicare from paying for Viagra and other drugs for erectile dysfunction as part of Medicare's new prescription drug benefit; Bush administration officials say that, under their reading of new Medicare drug benefit, they had to pay for drugs like Viagra, Levitra and Cialis when they are prescribed; many members of Congress are concerned by new estimates of cost, which are far higher than they were told when they voted on bill in Nov 2003; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The issue of whether Medicare's new prescription drug benefit should cover such treatments is raising questions of ethics, economics, politics and health policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard K. Olney steers his motorized wheelchair toward the front door of the A.L.S. Center at the University of California, San Francisco. Like other patients who visit the center, he has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, a disease that destroys the nerves that control movement, trapping the victim in an increasingly inert body. It is inevitably fatal, often within a year or two.

headline.main: Longtime Expert on A.L.S. Now Knows It All Too Well

docs.abstract: Dr Richard K Olney, founder and former director of University of California, San Francisco, ALS Center, is now patient at very place where he authored more than 50 scientific papers on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; contributions to effort to find cure for ALS and his personal story described; Paula Olney, Richard's wife, comments on irony that he would be known for having ALS after working so hard to help others who had illness; he is participating in clinical trial he developed; one in 1000 people develop ALS; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Richard K. Olney, a neurologist and researcher, is now taking part in a clinical trial that he designed for patients with the disease.
